title: 112_s3214
content: The "Today's Entrepreneurs are America's Mentors Act" or the "TEAM Act" defines terms like "Administration" and "small business concern" under the Small Business Act. It also establishes an Office of Entrepreneurial Education within the Small Business Administration. The "TEAM Act" establishes the Office of Entrepreneurial Education within the Administration to provide innovative entrepreneurial information, education, and resources for prospective entrepreneurs and small business concerns. The Director of the Office manages online courses, publications, resources, and youth entrepreneurship programs. The "TEAM Act" aims to provide online resources and outreach to youth entrepreneurs, coordinate with service providers, share educational materials on financial literacy, and offer assistance to individuals interested in entrepreneurship. Additionally, it establishes a National Primary and Secondary School Entrepreneurial Education Program under the Office of Entrepreneurial Education. The "TEAM Act" establishes a program for grants to nonprofit organizations to provide technical assistance to schools for entrepreneurship education. Nonprofits must submit an application outlining project goals and partners involved. The "TEAM Act" establishes a grant program for nonprofit organizations to provide technical assistance for entrepreneurship education in schools. Nonprofits must submit an application detailing project goals, partners involved, individuals assisted, jobs created or saved, and other necessary information. $3,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2013 to 2015. Additionally, a report on best practices of entrepreneurial education and training programs is required within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Director of the Office of Entrepreneurial Education must submit a report on best practices of entrepreneurial education and training programs within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The report will include descriptions of exemplary programs at national, regional, state, and local levels, as well as a summary of programs by the Federal Government, state and local governments, nonprofits, and private sector groups. The Master of Business Administration Scholarship Pilot Program is established under Section 4 of the Act. The Administrator may award up to 100 scholarships of $1,500 each to MBA students on a competitive basis. Recipients must provide free assistance to small businesses for 1-2 weeks. At least 50% of recipients must be students from institutions with limited entrepreneurship opportunities. The Administrator awards scholarships to MBA students for providing free assistance to small businesses. Recipients must support various entrepreneurial projects and have a mentor. Recipients and businesses must provide data on the assistance provided and employment status. The scholarship recipients must provide information on the assistance given and employment status for 3 years after graduation. Failure to comply results in the scholarship being treated as a loan. $200,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2013 to 2015. No scholarships will be awarded after September 30, 2015. SEC. 5. REGIONAL ENTREPRENEURIAL COMPETITIONS. The Administrator will establish a program for regional competitions and a national conference to address challenges through entrepreneurial research and business planning. Regional offices will identify issues, sponsor competitions for small businesses, and collaborate with various entities to promote the competition and request proposals. The Administrator will organize a national conference for presenting selected research and business plans from regional competitions. 11 employees will be designated for a panel to review the plans. The Administrator will designate 11 employees to serve on a panel that will select the best research and business plans from each region at the national conference. A grant of $50,000 will be awarded to each selected plan. The Administrator will award a $50,000 grant to selected plans. Recipients must submit a report within 1 year. $750,000 is authorized for this section. The Administrator, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The report will include recommendations for legislation to forgive and defer student loans to support youth entrepreneurship and business formation.
